content:
lass="word-wrap-span">Until last month, a Greek citizen could be jailed for up to two years for “publicly and maliciously blaspheming” against lass="word-wrap-span">God, against the Greek lass="word-wrap-span">Orthodox church or “any other permitted religion.” In one of its last acts before losing an election, a leftist government quietly dropped this article as part of a revision of the criminal code.

lass="word-wrap-span">The law had not fallen into lass="word-wrap-span">disuse; a man had been sentenced to a ten-month term in 2012 for lass="word-wrap-span">facetiously comparing a famous monk to a pasta dish. It took him five years to appeal and clear his name. (lass="word-wrap-span">Short prison terms can lass="word-wrap-span">generally be bought off in lass="word-wrap-span">Greece, so lass="word-wrap-span">The humourist faced little risk of going to jail. lass="word-wrap-span">But lass="word-wrap-span">The case stirred strong emotions.)

lass="word-wrap-span">New lass="word-wrap-span">Zealand also lass="word-wrap-span">lass="word-wrap-span">abolished its virtually lass="word-wrap-span">dormant lass="word-wrap-span">blasphemy law in lass="word-wrap-span">March; it was the seventh democracy to take this step since 2015. In most liberal-minded countries, it is now agreed that outlawing lass="word-wrap-span">blasphemy, even through mildish and half-forgotten laws, sets a bad example to the states where bans are applied lass="word-wrap-span">harshly, including the 40 or so which prescribe prison terms and at least five where the penalty can be death.

Scotland and lass="word-wrap-span">Northern Ireland are now among the few lass="word-wrap-span">Democratic lass="word-wrap-span">jurisdictions where lass="word-wrap-span">blasphemy is still punishable. In those places, too, it seems likely that the law will eventually be changed, even though vocal lobbies may lass="word-wrap-span">drag their feet. lass="word-wrap-span">Northern Ireland’s lass="word-wrap-span">Democratic lass="word-wrap-span">Unionist lass="word-wrap-span">Party, whose MPs prop up the British government, is resisting change.

lass="word-wrap-span">Yet despite this liberalising trend, people who monitor the freedom of religion-related speech in the lass="word-wrap-span">West, especially lass="word-wrap-span">Europe, see no reason to be lass="word-wrap-span">complacent. lass="word-wrap-span">Whether because of old habits that die hard, or because of new lass="word-wrap-span">ideas about how to manage diverse societies, threats to the freedom of expression are still palpable and in some ways rising, they say.

As examples of the unpleasant experiences that “trouble-makers” in the field of religion can still suffer, lass="word-wrap-span">campaigners reel off a list of cases. A retired teacher in lass="word-wrap-span">Germany who lass="word-wrap-span">adorned his car with anti-lass="word-wrap-span">Christian slogans was fined €500 ($560) in 2016; last year, a Spanish actor was arrested after ridiculing lass="word-wrap-span">God and the lass="word-wrap-span">Virgin Mary on Facebook; earlier this year, a lass="word-wrap-span">Christian street preacher from Africa was lass="word-wrap-span">detained by police in London and moved elsewhere after refusing to tone down the message that his faith was the only true one. (lass="word-wrap-span">Neither the actor nor the preacher was charged eventually.)

lass="word-wrap-span">More lass="word-wrap-span">fundamentally, lass="word-wrap-span">campaigners for free speech are worried by the rise in the seductive but dangerous notion that people have a right not to be offended. Kenan Malik, a British writer, has argued that in the lass="word-wrap-span">Western world, secular notions of “offence” and the protection of different communities’ feelings are taking the place of lass="word-wrap-span">blasphemy laws lass="word-wrap-span">explicitly based on religion.

In fact, Mr Malik maintains, there is no real lass="word-wrap-span">contradiction between the formal lass="word-wrap-span">abolition of lass="word-wrap-span">Blasphemy legislation and the secular world’s lass="word-wrap-span">ambivalent lass="word-wrap-span">interpretation of “hate speech” or lass="word-wrap-span">extremism to lass="word-wrap-span">encompass meanings that can easily shut down all vigorous religious debate. lass="word-wrap-span">Blasphemy is not so much being decriminalised as redefined.

Stephen Evans of the lass="word-wrap-span">National lass="word-wrap-span">Secular lass="word-wrap-span">Society, a lobby group, says the British right to robust philosophical debate survived only by the skin of its teeth in 2006, when legislation on religious and racial lass="word-wrap-span">hatred was crafted. In its final lass="word-wrap-span">iteration, it specified that religion-related speech had to be threatening as well as lass="word-wrap-span">abusive and lass="word-wrap-span">insulting to break the law. lass="word-wrap-span">But many people would still like to lower the bar, Mr Evans notes. He points to a dangerous tendency to see freedom of speech as a necessary evil rather than a positive good.

lass="word-wrap-span">For some lass="word-wrap-span">campaigners, the cause of free speech in lass="word-wrap-span">Europe remains under the shadow of a ruling from the lass="word-wrap-span">European lass="word-wrap-span">Court of lass="word-wrap-span">Human lass="word-wrap-span">Rights last lass="word-wrap-span">October: it upheld the lass="word-wrap-span">conviction of an Austrian woman who was found guilty of causing offence with disparaging remarks about Islam.

It is the court’s reasoning, as much as its conclusion, that liberty lass="word-wrap-span">advocates find troubling. lass="word-wrap-span">States could take action to curb religion-related speech “where such expressions go beyond the limits of a critical lass="word-wrap-span">denial of other people’s religious beliefs and are likely to lass="word-wrap-span">lass="word-wrap-span">incite religious lass="word-wrap-span">intolerance, for example in the event of an lass="word-wrap-span">improper or even lass="word-wrap-span">abusive attack on an object of religious veneration,” the ECHR judges found.

lass="word-wrap-span">Jacob Mchangama, a Danish lawyer who has lass="word-wrap-span">chronicled lass="word-wrap-span">The history of free speech in lass="word-wrap-span">The lass="word-wrap-span">West, says this loose language is a lass="word-wrap-span">lamentable regression for a part of lass="word-wrap-span">The world that spawned lass="word-wrap-span">The lass="word-wrap-span">Enlightenment. “It’s quite lass="word-wrap-span">ironic that lass="word-wrap-span">The ECHR should lass="word-wrap-span">emerge as lass="word-wrap-span">The last defender of [de lass="word-wrap-span">facto] lass="word-wrap-span">blasphemy bans in a lass="word-wrap-span">continent where brave philosophers were persecuted for violating religious lass="word-wrap-span">dogmas. lass="word-wrap-span">The court should be lass="word-wrap-span">The lass="word-wrap-span">guardian of lass="word-wrap-span">The rights which those philosophers pioneered.”

lass="word-wrap-span">Peter Tatchell, a gay-rights veteran who defends the liberty even of religious lass="word-wrap-span">conservatives, finds that advancing metaphysical lass="word-wrap-span">ideas is lass="word-wrap-span">generally unhindered in his home country, lass="word-wrap-span">Britain, “apart from the occasional over-zealous arrest of lass="word-wrap-span">bigoted preachers.”

lass="word-wrap-span">However, he adds, “it is getting more risky to criticise religious lass="word-wrap-span">ideas. lass="word-wrap-span">Some people have been vilified, arrested or banned from speaking on lass="word-wrap-span">The grounds that lass="word-wrap-span">Their lass="word-wrap-span">critique of religion caused offence to faith communities.” As a close and often contrarian observer of free-speech controversies, he finds that lass="word-wrap-span">The lass="word-wrap-span">devout can apply double standards: “lass="word-wrap-span">Conservative religious lass="word-wrap-span">adherents demand lass="word-wrap-span">The freedom to say what lass="word-wrap-span">They like but don't extend that same right to olass="word-wrap-span">Thers who are critical of lass="word-wrap-span">Their religious standpoint. lass="word-wrap-span">The law and elements of public opinion lass="word-wrap-span">Sometimes seem to bend in lass="word-wrap-span">Their favour.”

lass="word-wrap-span">One mildly encouraging sign, perhaps, is that the British government has virtually given up its effort to find a precise legal definition of lass="word-wrap-span">extremism. Defining lass="word-wrap-span">extremism might sound like a good lass="word-wrap-span">idea, but for freedom lass="word-wrap-span">advocates, almost any definition proposed runs the risk of silencing the merely lass="word-wrap-span">eccentric. lass="word-wrap-span">Laws that criminalise open lass="word-wrap-span">lass="word-wrap-span">incitement to violence, which exist in all countries, should suffice, as these lass="word-wrap-span">advocates see things.

In a speech about lass="word-wrap-span">extremism last month Sajid Javid, who was then still lass="word-wrap-span">Britain’s home secretary, sounded a little-noticed note of lass="word-wrap-span">humility: “Of course you shouldn’t arrest everyone with a suspect view. I won’t be the thought-police; people are lass="word-wrap-span">entitled to hold and express their own views.”

Mr Javid’s words may not be those of a libertarian but they do reflect an internal debate in the British lass="word-wrap-span">establishment, involving legal experts and the police as well as civil servants and ministers, about how lass="word-wrap-span">extremist lass="word-wrap-span">ideas, whether religiously-inspired or otherwise, can best be countered.

Proscribing and punishing perceived lass="word-wrap-span">extremists, in the absence of any clear threat to harm others, does not seem to be the best way, at least for a country which took prlass="word-wrap-span">ide in letting any zealot sound off in the street about lass="word-wrap-span">heaven, hell and human destiny. lass="word-wrap-span">Britain’s unwritten political order, as the writer George lass="word-wrap-span">Orwell noted, has lass="word-wrap-span">always lass="word-wrap-span">cherished lass="word-wrap-span">eccentricity; in many other democracies, a formal, constitutional right to free speech reflects long struggles against lass="word-wrap-span">authoritarianism and theocracy. Removing traces of that theocracy, in the form of lass="word-wrap-span">blasphemy laws, doesn’t mean that liberty is safe.
